text:
Discovering things that developers leave behind
in video games has always been my jam.

Often times these things go hand in hand with
the mysteries that I would hunt down as a
kid.

I’d spend my days traversing these digital
landscapes looking for relics of the past,
or clues to a story that wasn’t quite told.

By now, I’ve covered a LOT in the Mario
Galaxy games…
But honestly, we’re just getting started.

And today’s video actually has us going
back to the desert again.

Mind you we’re not talking about the same
place those unreachable mushrooms were at
- which was Slipsand Galaxy.

Today we’re turning back the clock and focusing
on one of the most expansive
levels in Super Mario Galaxy 1: Dusty Dune Galaxy.

Now when I say expansive, it’d kind of two
fold.

For one, the main planet we are on in this
galaxy is obviously enormous, but Dusty Dune

Galaxy also has a whopping seven stars to
collect here.

You’ll find yourself coming back here again
and again trying to collect them all in your
travels…
And that’s where we find ourselves today.

Playing through the various missions and noticing
something a bit peculiar on the horizon.

So the first two missions play out pretty
smoothly.

There isn’t really anything notable in these
areas, but it is important that get an understanding

of their foundation - especially Star 1, Soaring
on the Desert Winds.

On this star we traverse an enormous tower
in the center of the level, and regardless

of where you are in this galaxy, that tower
is always a focal point due to its size.

It’s important to remember the location
of it, because we’ll be coming back to it
shortly.

Now, on Star 3, Sunbaked Sand Castle, this
is where things get interesting.

Because halfway through the level is where
I ended up noticing something a bit strange.

After clearing the first disc-shaped planet,
which is the place you launch to after the

start of the level, you’ll find yourself
on a planet that keeps increasing and decreasing
in size.

Now this in itself isn’t strange, but it’s
what we can see in the background that is.

If we travel to the top of the planet with
the large sized pricker bush thing - honestly,

I don’t even know what these things are
called, but they’ll basically stab you to
death.

If we go up there, our camera pulls back for
a moment allowing to us to see a peculiar
launch star in the distance waaaaay down below.

It’s a bit annoying to do this because you
can’t access first person view due to the
planet constantly changing size.

Now at first glance, I thought “well maybe
this is from a different star mission, or

it’s a previous launch star I used earlier
in the level”.

In terms of distance, sometimes areas unload
and leave the objects behind.

You’ve probably heard me say this about
Grand Master Galaxy in Super Mario Galaxy

2 - where a mysterious floating launch star
in the distance appears to randomly be placed.

In that case, it’s only the previous map
section that unloaded, and due to our proximity
to the object, we can still see it loaded.
But that’s not what is happening here.

The area we started this level on isn’t
between these two pyramids, and beyond that,

the area this launch star is in is way off
course for how the level normally progresses
in any mission that I could recall.

But I did see it was near the large tower
I pointed out before, so that’s when I decided
to backtrack.

I exited the stage, and reselected Soaring
on the Desert Winds again.

I made my way to the tower at the end of the
stage, and began to climb.

Now since I was up above and looking down
before, I knew I had to figure out my positioning
in reference to where the star actually was.
But this is where I began scratching my head.

Upon entering first person view and looking
out across the sand, I couldn’t find the
star anywhere.

I was close enough where the object certainly
should have been loaded, but the space between
the two pyramids was blank.
So perhaps I wasn’t close enough.

I figured, I might as well check and see if
the star is there, so I climbed a bit higher

and long jumped off the tower towards where
the star was…
But there’s a problem with that too.

This entire tower is encased in giant, invisible
walls a couple meters out from where the tower
is.

Your character won’t bop their head, but
it’ll hold them in place and prevent them
from moving.

But even with the added distance, no star
was to be found.

So this is when I realized this launch star
only appears in one scenario out of the entire
level - and that is Sunbaked Sand Castle.

It is an object bound to that set of rules,
and thus, only appears when it is activated.

It’s very similar to the inaccessible moon
I found in Spin Dig Galaxy, where you can’t

actually get to it because it’s only present
on a mission that doesn’t take you to that
part of the map.

So I busted out the old flying hack again
and traveled over to this strange launch star.

Weird enough, making your way to the launch
star itself actually inverts gravity for the

entire level - meaning instead of getting
pulled towards the planet, you’re pushed
into the sky.

Kinda seemed bizarre as it basically forces
you away from the launch star - on one hand,

you have deadly sand if you go to far, and
on the other, you’ll be ejected into space

to die if you cut the power to your flight
not close enough.

But entering this launch star, basically takes
you waaaaay back up into the atmosphere and

ontop of the final area for the Sunbaked Sand
Castle mission.

It’s the same destination as the star that
normally takes you to that planet…
Which is strange.

And this is where there are two possible explanations
for how this launch star got here, and what
it was once used for:

This unreachable launch star was a copy and
paste of the launch star at the end of the

level, probably set aside while the developer
was linking all the various planets together.

Once the level was completed the developer
forgot to delete it due to this star’s color
blending in so well with the shifting sand.

Or explanation 2: Sunbaked Sand Castle, or
rather the early form of Star 3, actually
used to have more ground-based sections.

We obviously start the map out near the ground
before being propelled into the sky, but it’s

possible that before heading upwards, we actually
used to move outwards.

Instead of having only one ground-based area,
there were many - and it’s possible that

even the disc-shaped planets may have been
actually ground-based areas where the sandy
towers rose out of.

It’s make sense given the giant adjacent
tower nearby.

Perhaps this launch star down here is an asset
that was forgotten during the deletion or
moving process.

Considering this, it’s actually neat to
think that this lost relic could be a hint
at how this level evolved over time.

A lost launch star defended on all sides from
deadly sand, reversed gravity, and sky high
invisible walls…

Quite the defense set up if I must say so
myself.

Another mysterious entity left behind by a
developer that we can never ask what its purpose
was once for.

The unreachable launch star of Dusty Dune
Galaxy…

But now that I’ve shared that, have you
ever tried to reach this launch star?
Make any other weird discoveries of your own?
Let me know in the comments below!
